newsitem.title: USA: Clinton would revive health care plan, Dole says.
newsitem.headline: Clinton would revive health care plan, Dole says.

text.p: Republican presidential nominee Bob Dole searched for suburban votes on Sunday suggesting President Bill Clinton would try to revive a "government takeover" of health care if re-elected.
During a one-day trip to this Chicago area town, Dole tried to portray the president as a liberal who would use a second term to spend freely on government programs.
"Now the election is just around the corner," Dole said in prepared remarks, "so President Clinton will do everything he can to hide his liberal agenda."

Speaking at the College of Lake County rally, Dole said it was three years ago to the day that Clinton unveiled his health care insurance plan to cover most Americans, a plan that died in Congress after a fierce national debate.

The plan, Dole said, would have cost $1.5 trillion and "created 50 brand new federal bureaucracies, countless new laws and federal penalties and put one-seventh of the U.S. economy under government control ...(and) imposed 17 new taxes."

"There are hints that if re-elected, President Clinton might take another shot at a government takeover of health care," Dole added. "Of course he says 'the era of big government is over.' As usual his actions tell a different story than his words."

Dole's press secretary Nelson Warfield said the purpose of his speech was to wish a "happy anniversary to Bill Clinton's big government scheme and remind voters what's ahead if Bill Clinton never has to face voters again."
This will be a theme as the campaign enters the final six weeks of the campaign to the Nov. 5 election, Warfield said.
Clinton's press secretary Joe Lockhart fired back, saying Dole had passed no significant health care reform bills as majority leader of the first Republican Congress in 40 years.
"Bob Dole's negative attacks can't hide his do-nothing record," he said in a statement.

Lockhart said it was only after Dole quit the Senate to concentrate on his presidential bid that Congress passed a Clinton-backed health-care bill allowing people to keep insurance if they change jobs or have a pre-existing illness.
Dole also hammered away at other familiar themes, including his proposed 15 percent income tax cut and an attack on Clinton's drug policies.
"There are over a million more children using drugs today than the day Bill Clinton was elected," Dole said. "That's enough to fill every football stadium in America."

In an attempt to lower expectations, Warfield said that Clinton is the favorite going into the presidential debates despite Dole's 35 years in Congress as a veteran of many debates before he resigned for full-time campaigning.
"Clinton comes into the debates with a substantial advantage," Warfield told reporters. "He's glib and agile, but I'm confident that Sen. Dole can hold his own."

Dole won a tactical victory on Saturday when negotiators decided to exclude Reform Party candidate Ross Perot from the two presidential debates, Oct. 6 in Hartford, Connecticut, and Oct. 16 in San Diego. That is what Dole wanted since his campaign believed Perot could cut into Dole's support.
Grayslake is part of a ring of suburban mostly Republican communities surrounding Chicago that Dole must carry if he wants to win Illinois.
A Reuters/Zogby poll last week showed Dole trailing Clinton by 16 percentage points in a state Clinton won over President George Bush four years ago.

A new CNN/USA Today/Gallup tracking poll conducted on Sept. 19-21 showed Dole trailing Clinton nationally by 19 percentage points, with the gap widening to 30 percentage points among likely women voters. Among men, Dole trailed by only six percentage points.
